demographics.employer_school: UC Santa Barbara - Junior, Computer Science

medical_history.history_of_present_illness: 21-year-old male college student presenting for routine follow-up. Patient reports overall good health but has been experiencing increased anxiety related to academic pressures. Also reports occasional heartburn after eating spicy foods. Denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or palpitations. Sleep has been irregular due to study schedule.

past_medical_history.notes: Diagnosed during freshman year of college. Well-controlled on current medication.
Mild symptoms, managed with lifestyle modifications and PRN antacids.
Symptoms worse in spring. Uses OTC antihistamines as needed.
Sustained during high school soccer. Full recovery with no residual symptoms.

surgical_history.notes: All four impacted wisdom teeth removed under general anesthesia.

family_history.notes: Diagnosed with HTN at age 45, DM at age 48. Well-controlled on medications.
Anxiety runs in maternal side of family.
Breast cancer diagnosed at 62, in remission after treatment.

recreational_drugs.history: Tried marijuana once in high school, no ongoing use

diet.notes: Eats at university dining halls. Trying to increase protein intake for fitness goals.

social_history.living_situation: Lives in off-campus apartment with 2 roommates

past.name: Amoxicillin
past.reason_stopped: Completed course - switched to azithromycin for future due to penicillin allergy development

immunizations.notes: Third and final dose of series

facility.name: UCSB Student Health Center
facility.address: Student Health Building, UC Santa Barbara, CA 93106

encounters.chief_complaint: Routine follow-up, anxiety check, and annual wellness exam
encounters.subjective: Alex presents for his annual wellness exam and medication follow-up. He reports his anxiety has been well-controlled on current sertraline dose. Notes occasional breakthrough anxiety during finals week but manageable with coping strategies learned in therapy. GERD symptoms have improved with omeprazole - only occasional heartburn when eating late at night. He has been exercising regularly 3-4 times per week with weight training and running. Diet could be improved - eating mostly at dining halls. Sleep remains somewhat irregular, averaging 6-7 hours on weeknights. No new concerns. Denies depression, suicidal ideation, chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, abdominal pain, changes in bowel habits, or urinary symptoms.

physical_exam.general: Well-developed, well-nourished young male in no acute distress. Alert and oriented x3. Pleasant and cooperative.
physical_exam.heent: Normocephalic, atraumatic. Pupils equal, round, reactive to light. TMs clear bilaterally. Oropharynx clear without erythema or exudate.
physical_exam.neck: Supple, no lymphadenopathy, no thyromegaly. Full range of motion.
physical_exam.cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. Normal S1, S2. No murmurs, rubs, or gallops. No peripheral edema.
physical_exam.respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. Normal respiratory effort.
physical_exam.abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Normal bowel sounds. No hepatosplenomegaly. Well-healed laparoscopic appendectomy scars.
physical_exam.musculoskeletal: Full range of motion in all extremities. No joint swelling or tenderness. Normal gait.
physical_exam.skin: Warm, dry, intact. No rashes or lesions.
physical_exam.neurological: Alert and oriented. Cranial nerves II-XII intact. Motor strength 5/5 throughout. Sensation intact. DTRs 2+ and symmetric.
physical_exam.psychiatric: Mood euthymic, affect appropriate. Good eye contact. Speech normal rate and rhythm. Thought process linear and goal-directed. No SI/HI.

plan: 1. Continue sertraline 50mg daily for anxiety - well-controlled at current dose. PHQ-9 score 4 (minimal depression). GAD-7 score 6 (mild anxiety).
2. Continue omeprazole 20mg daily for GERD. Reinforce lifestyle modifications: avoid eating 3 hours before bed, limit spicy/acidic foods, elevate head of bed.
3. Labs ordered: CBC, CMP, Lipid Panel - results pending. Will contact if abnormal.
4. Discussed LDL cholesterol slightly elevated at 110 (goal <100). Recommend dietary modifications: increase fiber, reduce saturated fat, continue exercise. Recheck lipids in 6 months.
5. Continue current exercise regimen. Encouraged to maintain protein intake for muscle building goals.
6. Sleep hygiene counseling provided. Recommend consistent sleep schedule, limit caffeine after 2pm, avoid screens 1 hour before bed.
7. EpiPen prescription renewed. Reviewed anaphylaxis action plan.
8. Immunizations up to date. Flu shot administered today.
9. Return to clinic in 3-4 months or sooner if concerns arise.
encounters.clinical_note: Alex is a 21-year-old male presenting for annual wellness exam and medication follow-up. Anxiety well-controlled on sertraline 50mg, GERD improved on omeprazole 20mg. Vitals: BP 118/76, HR 72, Temp 98.4°F, SpO2 99%, BMI 23.0. Physical exam unremarkable. Labs ordered. Plan: Continue current medications, lifestyle counseling for borderline elevated LDL, sleep hygiene education, return in 3-4 months.

encounters.subjective: Alex presents for quarterly psychiatric follow-up. Reports anxiety has been well-managed over the summer with fewer stressors. Concerned about upcoming fall quarter academic demands. Currently doing research assistant work which he enjoys. Sleeping better during summer - about 7-8 hours. No side effects from sertraline. Continues to exercise regularly which helps with mood. Denies panic attacks, depression, or suicidal ideation.
plan: 1. Continue sertraline 50mg daily - effective at current dose
2. PHQ-9: 3 (minimal). GAD-7: 5 (mild). Scores stable
3. Discussed strategies for managing academic stress in upcoming quarter
4. Encouraged continued exercise and healthy sleep habits
5. Continue monthly therapy sessions
6. Return in 3 months. Call sooner if symptoms worsen
encounters.clinical_note: Alex is a 21-year-old male with GAD presenting for medication follow-up. Anxiety well-controlled on sertraline 50mg during summer. Anticipatory anxiety about fall quarter discussed. Mental status exam within normal limits. PHQ-9: 3, GAD-7: 5. Plan: Continue current medication and therapy, coping strategies reviewed.

encounters.chief_complaint: Heartburn and acid reflux for 5 days
encounters.subjective: Alex presents with complaints of burning sensation in chest and throat, worse after meals and when lying down. Started about 5 days ago after eating spicy food at a friend's party. Has been using Tums with minimal relief. Also notes sour taste in mouth in the morning. Denies difficulty swallowing, weight loss, vomiting blood, or black stools. Reports increased stress due to midterms coming up.

physical_exam.cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs
physical_exam.abdomen: Soft, mild epigastric tenderness, no rebound or guarding, normal bowel sounds

plan: 1. Start omeprazole 20mg daily, take 30 minutes before breakfast
2. Lifestyle modifications: avoid eating 3 hours before bed, elevate head of bed 6 inches, avoid trigger foods (spicy, acidic, fatty, caffeine, chocolate, alcohol)
3. Avoid NSAIDs if possible
4. If symptoms persist after 4 weeks of treatment, will consider referral to GI for possible endoscopy
5. Return in 4-6 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen
encounters.clinical_note: Alex is a 21-year-old male presenting with 5-day history of heartburn and acid reflux symptoms. Vitals: BP 124/80, HR 76, Temp 98.6°F. Abdomen with mild epigastric tenderness. Assessment: GERD. Plan: Start omeprazole 20mg daily, lifestyle modifications counseling, follow up in 4-6 weeks.

encounters.chief_complaint: Sore throat and difficulty swallowing for 3 days
encounters.subjective: Alex presents with sore throat that started 3 days ago. Reports pain with swallowing, especially solid foods. Denies fever, cough, runny nose, or ear pain. Roommate had similar symptoms last week. Has been taking ibuprofen with some relief.

physical_exam.heent: Pharynx erythematous without exudates. Tonsils 2+ bilaterally without exudates. Tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy

plan: 1. Supportive care - rest, hydration, salt water gargles
2. Continue ibuprofen 400mg every 6 hours as needed for pain (note: patient has no NSAID allergy)
3. Throat lozenges as needed
4. Return if fever develops, symptoms worsen, or not improving in 5-7 days
encounters.clinical_note: Alex is a 21-year-old male with 3-day history of sore throat and odynophagia. Low-grade fever at 99.2°F. Pharynx erythematous, rapid strep negative. Assessment: Viral pharyngitis. Plan: Supportive care with rest, fluids, and ibuprofen PRN.

health_maintenance.colonoscopy_due: Not yet indicated (age-based screening begins at 45)

advance_directives.notes: Patient is young and healthy. Has not completed advance directives. Discussed briefly - patient states he will consider completing in the future.
